review:
Интересный симулятор развозчика пиццы.
Скорость и количество заказов повышается с каждым уровнем.
Но мне кажется что у бонустных уровней есть проблема.
С каждой собранной пиццой уменьшается время на сборку новой.
А уменьшится оно может до двух секунд. Как я успею за эти две секунды разложить ингредиенты разработчик не подумал. Но удовольствие от игрового процесса получить смог.
Есть ограничения по времени.

[b][i]-Педя Мох[/i][/b]

"Pizza Frenzy Delux"

Spielt zuerst die Demo, da habt ihr 60 Minuten kostenlose Testzeit.

Es dauert zwar einwenig, bis man das Spielprinzip überhaupt versteht.

Aber wenn man sich beeilt, schafft man in der Demo-Version schon 70% des Geamtspieles.

Ich mag eigentlich Frenzy-Spiele sehr, aber das hier macht nicht wirklich Spaß.

Sucht euch andere Spiele, das hier ist es nicht Wert.

The game is old and i bought it just to be able to say i have every Counter-Strike game but when i finally played it (after like 2 years of owning it) i can say that it provided a good 20 minutes of fun before i got bored.
It's just Counter-Strike if it was a plotless CoD mobile game.
Sure you have multiplayer on it but there's literally no one playing it (except possibly a few Russians).
In my non-professional opinion, just play CS2. Or if you're searching for an OG Counter-Strike experience, get CSS.

Ever wondered what would happen if you threw thousands of tiny, colorful stick figures into a battlefield and let chaos ensue? Welcome to Multiwinia.

This game takes the charming aesthetics of Darwinia and cranks up the mayhem with fast-paced, strategic battles. Whether you're capturing spawn points, dominating hills, or racing to launch rockets, every mode is a delightful blend of strategy and arcade action.

The simplicity of controls means you can jump right in, but don't be fooled—mastering the art of Multiwinian warfare requires cunning tactics and a penchant for unpredictability. Plus, the retro-inspired graphics are a nostalgic treat for the eyes.

✅ Fast, frenetic, and fun
✅ Variety of game modes keeps things fresh
✅ Perfect blend of strategy and chaos
❌ Multiplayer community isn't as bustling as it once was, but AI opponents offer solid competition

Final Verdict:
10/10 – Would lead my pixelated army to glorious victory (or hilarious defeat) again.
The graphics are pixelated, but the gameplay is fun.

I didn't enjoy Darwinia much, so I wasn't expecting to enjoy Multiwinia either, but I figured I might as well check it out since I got both games in a bundle. I was pleasantly surprised to find that some of the things I disliked about Darwinia had been improved, like the painfully slow speed of units and some of the clunkyness around controlling them, and the game feels quite different in general. Unfortunately, despite the six different gamemodes and variety of different maps, it felt like this game got stale extremely quickly, and the gameplay just wasn't complex enough to stay interesting for long.

Regardless of the ultimate objective, most of the gameplay involves selecting groups of units and moving them around the map. You don't really have much control over what they do. If there's something to interact with nearby, they'll probably interact with it. If there's enemies around, they'll probably attack. It's never quite guaranteed though, and sometimes they'll just stand around doing nothing, or wander away. The visual feedback from combat isn't great either, and it's hard to tell exactly why you're winning or losing battles other than the assumption that the winning side had a larger number of units. Crates can be added, which can be collected to provide various items, which make things a bit more interesting. However, where these items spawn is fairly random and feels pretty unfair sometimes, and the power of various items varies wildly, so adding crates does little more than add more luck to the game. You can play this game against friends online or against AI, and playing with friends is definitely more enjoyable, although the gameplay felt about the same in both cases. I don't know if that's because the AI is decent or if it's because this game is so simplistic that it's not hard to design an AI to play it.

The game has the same low poly, simplistic aesthetic as Darwinia, and it looks neat. The game ran well, and I didn't encounter any obvious bugs, other than the same clunky controls when controlling the armor units that Darwinia had.

[b]TL;DR[/b] This is an interesting sequel to Darwinia that shares the same aesthetic and has similar gameplay, although it makes some improvements to the speed of the game and the way units are controlled and used. The gameplay felt pretty simplistic though, with few objectives beyond trying to make sure you have more units than everyone else in every battle, and most additional complexity relies mainly on randomness, which doesn't feel satisfying either. Despite the fairly low price, I still can't recommend this game, as I just don't think there's enough entertaining content here to justify it.
